name: Comparing fractions with different numerators and different denominators

skills.name: Use inequality notation to order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number
Use inequality notation to order fractions whose denominators are not multiples of the same number

explanations.A: Substituting the values in: a/b = 4/3 = 1⅓ and b/a = ¾. We know that 1⅓ > ¾, meaning Answer A is correct.
explanations.B: Not quite. Try substituting in the values given for a and b to see why a/b is NOT less than b/a. Remember common denominators can help us compare fractions.
explanations.C: Not quite. Two fractions are equivalent if you can multiply (or divide) the numerator and denominator, of one of the fractions, by the same number to get the other fraction. This is not the case here. Try substituting in the values for a and b and then use equivalent fractions to give them common denominators so that you can compare them.
explanations.D: Not quite. There is enough information to work out what symbol the star should be. Try replacing the values of a and b with 3 and 4, and then find a common denominator, to see if these fractions are equal or if one is bigger than the other.

explanations.A: Not quite. Try substituting in the values given for a and b to see why 4a/b is NOT more than b/a. Remembering that the fraction line means divide will help you compare these fractions.
explanations.B: Substituting the values in: (4a)/b = (4 ✕ 1)/4 = 4/4 = 1 and b/a = 4/1 = 4. We know that 1 < 4, meaning Answer B is correct.
explanations.C: Not quite. Try substituting in the values given for a and b to see why 4a/b is NOT equal to b/a. Remembering that the fraction line means divide will help you compare these fractions.
explanations.D: Not quite. There is enough information to work out what symbol the star should be. Try replacing the values of a and b with 1 and 4, and then use the fact that the fraction line means divide to compare these fractions.

explanations.B: Not quite. This fraction is equivalent to 4/5. Remember <' means 'less than'.
explanations.C: It is easier to compare fractions when they have the same denominator: 4/5 = 8/10. Then, because 8 < 9 and the denominators are now the same, it is true that 4/5 < 9/10.
explanations.D: Not quite. Remember <' means 'less than'. If fractions have the same numerators, the larger the denominator, the smaller the fraction.

explanations.A: What happens if you find an equivalent fraction of 3/8 with a denominator of 16? Is this fraction smaller or larger than 4/16?
explanations.B: Not quite. This fraction is equivalent to 3/8. Remember <' means 'less than'.
explanations.C: Not quite. Remember <' means 'less than'. If fractions have the same numerators, the larger the denominator, the smaller the fraction.
explanations.D: It is easier to compare fractions when they have the same denominator: 3/8 = 12/32. Then, because 12 < 14 and the denominators are now the same, it is true that 3/8 < 14/32.

explanations.A: Not quite. Try simplifying both of these fractions first.
explanations.B: Not quite. Try simplifying both of these fractions first.
explanations.C: It is easier to compare fractions when they have the same denominator. Here we can simplify both fractions to get 4/6 = 2/3 and 10/15 = 2/3,so these fractions are equal.
explanations.D: This sign (≈) means approximately equal to. Try simplifying both of these fractions first.

explanations.A: Not quite. Try forming equivalent fractions with the same denominator. Remember '>' means 'greater than'.
explanations.B: It is easier to compare fractions when they have the same denominator. 9 and 12 have lowest common multiple of 36. So we can use this as our denominator. 5/9 = 20/36 and 7/12 = 21/36. And so 20/36 < 21/36, which means 5/9 < 7/12.
explanations.C: Not quite. Try forming equivalent fractions with the same denominator.
explanations.D: This sign (≈) means approximately equal to. Try forming equivalent fractions with the same denominator.

explanations.A: First, you need to find equivalent fractions with the same denominators to be able to compare them.
explanations.B: We need to find equivalent fractions, all with the same denominator. If we put all three fractions over 24, we get 14/24, 15/24 and 16/24. Then we can just compare the numerators.
explanations.C: I think you have just compared the numerators. First, you need to find equivalent fractions with the same denominators to be able to compare them.
explanations.D: First, you need to find equivalent fractions with the same denominator to be able to compare them.

explanations.A: First, you need to find equivalent fractions with the same denominator to be able to compare them.
explanations.B: I think you have just compared the numerators. First, you need to find equivalent fractions with the same denominator to be able to compare them.
explanations.C: First, you need to find equivalent fractions with the same denominator to be able to compare them.
explanations.D: We need to find equivalent fractions with the same denominator. If we put them over 90 we get 45/90, 54/90 and 40/90. Then we can just compare the numerators.

explanations.A: It's easier to compare fractions if they have a common denominator - can you find a common multiple of 3 and 9? Remember the smaller side of the inequality sign points at the smaller number.
explanations.B: It's easier to compare fractions if they have a common denominator - can you find a common multiple of 3 and 9? Remember the smaller side of the inequality sign points at the smaller number.
explanations.C: 2/3 is equivalent to 6/9. 6 is greater than 5 so we need a greater than sign. Remember the smaller side of the inequality sign points at the smaller number.
explanations.D: This symbol means two things are identical in value, but these two fractions aren't the same, so we need an inequality sign to show which is greater. Remember the smaller side of the inequality sign points at the smaller number.

explanations.A: 2/5 is equivalent to 8/20 (multiply numerator and denominator by 4). 3/20 is less than 8/20 so we need a less than sign.
explanations.B: These two fractions aren't equal, so we need an inequality sign to show which is greater. Remember the smaller side of the inequality sign points at the smaller number.
explanations.C: First, you need to put these over a common denominator so you can compare them. Remember the smaller side of the inequality sign points at the smaller number.
explanations.D: This symbol means two things are identical in value, but these two fractions aren't equal, so we need an inequality sign to show which is greater. Remember the smaller side of the inequality sign points at the smaller number.
